snippet: As policy makers know well — and Germany perhaps better than any — major debt overhangs are solved only by writing down the debt. And the longer the delay, the deeper the pain.
abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column points out historical pattern showing that major sovereign debts are only solved after big write-downs of that debt, as evidenced by Germany's 1953 debt deal; contends general lesson on debt is one that has to be relearned over and over, and that now applies to Greece's financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: As policy makers know well — and Germany perhaps better than any — major debt overhangs are solved only by writing down the debt. And the longer the delay, the deeper the pain.

headline.print_headline: Germans Forget Postwar History Lesson on Debt Relief in Greece Crisis
